data.body:

1. Show QuickPick of the Git Project Manager extension
2. Before the promise resolve, type part of the project name in the quickpick input box
3. The list is not filtered, but if you type anything else, the filter starts

data.title: How to reorder itens on QuickPick based on user inputs
data.body:
How can I reorder my quick pick items, based on user inputs. 

I have an [active issue](https://github.com/felipecaputo/git-project-manager/issues/29) in my extension asking to change the order of items.

Searching the issues, I've found #1795 that shows that I can use `onDidChangeInput` to get the input from user, but how can I update my list, changing the items order?

Or maybe quick pick could have an option that allows it to order the list after user inputs, in the same way Ctrl + P do when searching for files

data.title: In Mac OS, when updating as a user other than the installer, the update never succeeds
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install as one user
2. Run auto-update as another

Adding the other user with read & write permissions does not resolve the problem

It seems to be looking in /var/root/Library for the update package instead of the library of the user who was running VSCode.

Log file:

```
Nov 17 08:20:14 XXXX ShipIt[21393]: Installation error: Error Domain=SQRLShipItRequestErrorDomain Code=2 "Could not read update request" UserInfo={NSLocalizedDescription=Could not read update request, NSUnderlyingError=0x7fad28c083a0 {Error Domain=NSCocoaErrorDomain Code=260 "The file “ShipItState.plist” couldn’t be opened because there is no such file." UserInfo={NSFilePath=/var/root/Library/Caches/com.microsoft.VSCode.ShipIt/ShipItState.plist, NSUnderlyingError=0x7fad28c07540 {Error Domain=NSPOSIXErrorDomain Code=2 "No such file or directory"}}}}
Nov 17 08:20:14 XXXX com.apple.xpc.launchd[1] (com.microsoft.VSCode.ShipIt[21393]): Service exited with abnormal code: 1
Nov 17 08:20:14 XXXX com.apple.xpc.launchd[1] (com.microsoft.VSCode.ShipIt): Service only ran for 0 seconds. Pushing respawn out by 2 seconds.
```

data.title: Open files in respective windows that have parent folder open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: 10

If you have two folders open in Code, say

    C:\project1
    C:\project2

And you opened a file from Windows File Explorer (either though context menu, or default associated application)

    C:\project2\some-file.js

It opens in the last Code window that was active. If it was the `C:\project1` Code windows, it opens in that. 

Expected behavior:

For the files being opened, Code should check to see if there's a project window open corresponding to the file's parent folder (walking up the parents as needed), and if it find such a Code window already opened it should open that file in that window.

In this case the `C:\project2\some-file.js` should open in `C:\project2` Code window, regardless of whether it was the `C:\project1` that was last active.

data.title: Avoid checking for backups on each resolve() of file/untitled
data.body: I see we only use it to find out if we should load a backup from disk when opening a file. Can we not just always try to load the backup and handle the error case? That should save us 1 IO operation.


data.title: pfs.writeFile should serialize parallel calls to writeFile
data.body:
According to the node.js docs, `fs.writeFile` is not safe to be used in parallel without waiting for the callback to be triggered:

> Note that it is unsafe to use `fs.writeFile` multiple times on the same file without waiting for the callback. For this scenario, `fs.createWriteStream` is strongly recommended.

@Tyriar I notice that you are using the file service to write backups and you just fire the calls to `updateContent` without checking for running `updateContent` calls for a given resource. This might bite us on slow file systems and could lead to corrupt backups. 

In the file land I am actually doing the serialization from the outside (no 2 saves ever run at the same time for the same file).

data.title: Merge IBackupService and IBackupModelService
data.body: I am not sure why IBackupModelService exists, it does not have any methods. Imho we should not add services that do not provide any functionality. If you need something to start listening and do work, just use a workbench contribution instead.

data.body:

data.title: Test: zen mode
data.body:
- [x] win @seanmcbreen 
- [x] os x @chrisdias 
- [x] linux @bgashler1 

Complexity: 3
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12940

As per popular demand we have added zen mode to vscode. Verify:
* Going in and out of zen mode is a smooth process (view menu, command palette, keybinding)
* Zen mode hides all workbench parts and goes into full screen
* You are still able to open workbench parts (sidebar, panel...) in zen mode
* Going out of full screen while in zen mode takes you out of zen mode
* Setting `workbench.fullScreenZenMode` is respected

data.title: Renaming files before saving deletes contents
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|typescript-react-snippets|abotteram|0.1.9|
|Theme-azure|gerane|0.0.2|
|jsx|TwentyChung|0.0.1|
|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.2.2|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|1.0.3|

---
Although this may be by design, it is different behavior compared to Visual Studio and other editors I have used. I typed a lot of code into a js file and when I renamed it prior to saving it, it wiped out all my code. It happened to me a couple times and now that I understand what is happening I'll be more careful in the future, but it would be nice if behavior didn't occur.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a js file and type code in it
2. Before saving, rename the file
3. Acknowledge the prompt

data.body:
In an effort to attract many unexperienced programmers into open source projects, many have been adopting the approach of labeling the issues as "Beginner Friendly" or "Newbie" when appropriated so newcomers can jump into open source dev without much hassle. 

More on this:
http://contributor-covenant.org/
https://opensource.com/life/16/1/6-beginner-open-source

data.title: IBackupFileService should not be aware of getWorkspaceBackupPaths
data.body:
I am wondering why each `IBackupFileService` needs to be aware of `workspaces.json` and the contents. To me a backup file service is being created on exactly one backup workspace (determined by `IWorkspaceContextService`) and thats it. With a dependency to `workspaces.json`, this service steps into the territory of `IBackupMainService` and that smells of debt. 

I would like to understand why this is really needed?

The only use case seems to be the already very complicated `backupBeforeShutdown` conditions in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/services/backup/node/backupService.ts#L135 which are impossible for me to understand quickly even with the comments.

data.title: Autocompletion of HTML does not use cases and puts a closing tag with all lower case letters
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1 (1.7.1) 02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6 (15G1108)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In a .html file open a custom tag
2. Try to close that tag with the autocomplate functionality of VS Code (Ctrl + Space > Tab)
3. The closing tag is in all lower case letters and ignores the casing of the original opening tag

Example:
input:

`<TestTag>`

-write `<`
- press "Ctrl + Space"
- press "Tab" to autocomplate the closing tag

output (result):
`<TestTag></testtag>`

In the previous 1.6.x version this used to work as expected leading to an output of 
`<TestTest></TestTest>` 

Is this a bug or a feature and if so how can I revert/fix it.

data.title: Why does each opened folder cause a change to workspaces.json?
data.body:
I find that one reason for potential stale backups (that is, a backup workspace without backups) is that we add a workspace to the `workspaces.json `file as soon as we open a folder. Why is that? Wouldn't it make more sense to update `workspaces.json` as soon as the first backup is written?

Source: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/code/electron-main/windows.ts#L482

data.title: The C# 'Generate variable' feature produces nothing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|Angular2|johnpapa|1.0.2|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.5.2|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.2.2|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Create a new C# class
2.In any method or constructor introduce a new variable, e.g. _foo = 10;
3.Place the cursor on the variable name and Ctrl + .
4. Select 'Generate variable'

The expectation is that there will be a class-level field, e.g. private int _foo but there is nothing whatsoever.

data.title: Configurable/Themable squiggles

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When you click on a variable, all variables with the same name are highlighted. It is possible to change that background color? I can't find it anywhere in the source (but anyway there is alpha opacity for sure, so i don't know the real color) and looks like is not themeable. It doesn't appear in the devtools also.

The same happens for the red line of errors and green line of warnings, i know this is not themeable but there is no way to change it even messing with core files?
